comments.commentBody:
Infants and children who are adopted, either given up lovingly or because of abandonment, all suffer, arguably, some degree of "primal wounding", a pathology that leaves a permanent scar on one's heart/psyche. Even an infant, who doesn't yet have the capacity to intellectually understand what is happening, FEELS something terribly wrong is happening. It leaves a deep and permanent scar.

The consequences of this primal wound influences a person's behavior, such as trusting people, commitment, anger, etc., as well as treatment of others. The need to ultra-control one's environment is not unusual among adoptees.

Despite the lifelong, profound, permanent hurt that Jobs endured, he was able to still be incredibly creative, productive, and brilliant. The way he handled this 'dark side' of his made him even more remarkable....and perhaps his nastiness was a fallout. (At least he didn't channel his anger toward a life of crime against society.) In fact, without that dark side, he may not have been as driven as he was.

The people who stuck with him, professionally and personally, accepted....and validated....him. Validation for a tormented soul is huge medicine. I can totally understand why he refused to make contact with this father, who was at least one half the source of his primal wound. Sad footnote to a brilliant life. Rest in peace, Mr Jobs.

After reading this piece, the thought which comes to mind is why. Why are you making this case against a man whose memory clearly means a lot to many people, a man who was assassinated 48 years ago? What is your motivation?

If it is to bring truth to light, it's important to remember that what you have written is merely a perspective, not truth. To state that some beliefs of others are a 'myth' reveals the tainted prism through which you view his life and accomplishments.

Why is it that some Republicans seem intent on attempting to skewer reputations?
I can only think that somehow his legacy is threatening to you and those of your mindset, which to me is a rewriting of history. It's sad really that someone with a keyboard can write things like your column, and somehow manage to get it published.
I have input from Hansen for the followup piece on sensitivity that's coming.

I think the Houston Chronicle link misses the point on why 350 ppm in the most important number in the world today. It has to do with the response to warming that is mid-range, not extreme. And, interestingly, the last glacial maximum, explored in this study, is still well within the linear response of climate to forcing in fig. 30 of Hansen's book "Storms of My Grandchildren", and thus does not have much to do with runaway to snowball conditions, the risk at the low end of carbon dioxide concentration.

Andy has been accused of false balance in the silly post about the bus recently, but if he is going to insinuate the word runaway in this context without consulting the expert, no balance or even extreme spasticity would be the better characterization.
I have input from Hansen for the followup piece on sensitivity that's coming.

Right, then.  Temperatures have plateaued, climate sensitivity is lower than assumed, and the credibility of the Team behind the Consensus Scientific Opinion is in tatters thanks to the brave leaks of a climate insider.  Mop up work will now commence and that would consist of demolishing the myth that the slow, gentle warming we are experiencing is somehow bad for us.  That and exposing the rent-seekers that are the real driving force behind the CAGW scare:  corporations like Enron and GE, carrion-eaters like George Soros, and an endless army of UN kleptocrats.

Thanks Jessie Henshaw, Philip Wenz and John Sully for adding to the conversation with thoughtful accurate writing. Jessie in particular highlights the most important problem, which transcends even the dangers of accelerating global warming, which this single study does not debunk no matter how much wishful thinking goes into promoting it.

We have come to believe that we must expand, and our lives are entrenched in a model of continuously enhanced consumption and entertainment. There is no question that we are a growing population on a finite globe, with a significant proportion of the world's population wishing to join the me first entitlements we enjoy, not to mention basics such as hot and cold running water and refrigeration, transportation, and the like.

Meanwhile, we have an entire industry bent on disinforming the public to the point that idiotic claims such as that "climategate" disproved and discredited science so we can all move on, promoted with varying degrees of literacy and dressed up skillfully by experts who study what real knowledge looks like and imitates it. While imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, it is fake.

Think about it - we have resources that are being used up and fewer and fewer further corners to exploit. This leads to the use of extreme fuel, which exploits more, a vicious cycle. We say to hell with the consequences, we want 3D on our cell phone, bigger houses, etc. etc.

Popular attacks on socialism ignore the fact that we all live with socialism every day, in sharing and having consideration for others. Blaming others first is not a good tactic for survival, but sharing is.

THE CRUCIAL SENSITIVITY ISSUE

The sensitivity issue is crucial,

It's similar to the fact that for your core temperature
the main issue is whether you are healthy
or whether you are sick - with a high sensitivity to temperature.

If you are healthy, then going outside in the cold
will not change your core temperature at all
Your thermostat is taking care of the stress.

If you are sick, you start to shiver from small changes
or for no reason at all…

Or, all the signs,
especially the lack of long term reaction to volcano stresses
point to our climate being very stable,
i.e. having low sensitivity to forcings.
Such as the minute effects of the
extra 1/100 of 1% of the atmosphere in
human added CO2.

The Greenland ice core data, as analyzed by Alley and al., shows that
the Medieval High, around AD 1100, was 2C higher than now.
http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/paleo/pubs/alley2000/alley2000.html

That's where the "2C limit" came from:
http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,686697-8,00.html
we were safe then so we should be safe again.

That wasn't alarmist enough,
So Mike Mann tried heavy handily
to obliterate the temperature record from history.
With bad statistics from two dozen trees…

Now on the same Greenland ice core record, some millennial oscillations, such as the current Medieval High 1100, Little Ice Age 1650, back upwards 1C/century slope,

some such oscillations end up where they began - which now would mean 2C higher about 2 centuries from now, before a new cooling cycle -

some others end lower or higher.

******************

For me the fact that mainland US,
the best measured place around,
didn't warm for a century could be a sign that
the millennial warming stopped.

The only places which did experience measured warming last century are
China, where it is hard to put measuring stations outside towns,
since towns are contiguous, and
up North, in Siberia, where at those low temperatures,
1C could easily come from heat radiation of the towns.

If we would enter a new cooling stage, by and large it would be bad.
Climate and crops during the Little Ice Age were horrendous…

******************

For climate scientists to settle on 2C warming from now
is simply an admission that the warming is natural

With the minute effects of added CO2 absorbed by the stable system
mostly, very likely, through cloud cover feedback...

The question here is how many trillions of dollars should we spend on fixing up the school bus. The climate "scientists" have been unmasked as at a minimum dishonest and conspiratorial and probably are simply "cargo cult scientists". They continually mistake correlation with causation.

There are real issues in protecting the environment. Things we can fix without destroying our economy. Obviously bad schemes, like Ethanol" and windmills need to be shut down. People are getting real cynical about anything related to the so called "environmental cause".

Resubmitted without name calling.

Bad news for those who had hoped CO2 might help stave off the next ice age.

While scaring the kids with climate horror stories may be a lost "cause," warmaggedon fundamentalists should take horror story heart. The global economy is looking pretty scary; bacteria and viruses are always mutating in scary ways; and suitcase nukes are likely to be in the hands Islamic fundamentalists soon.

So, there's some good horror story news to be found in moving from the world of science fictions to the world of facts.

As I mentioned, this post is to be followed by a substantial fresh look at the sensitivity question. I also greatly appreciated the interview you did with Nathan Urban (one of the study authors) at Tobis's Planet3 blog.

Really well done.

Andy,

While you nod in the direction of one paper not being definitive, I still feel like your post is giving this single paper a lot more weight than it deserves at this point, especially given the authors' own comments and criticisms that were made well before the embargo lifted.

The first thing I noticed when reading the draft was that the paper did not take the non-linearity of sensitivity at different climates into account. I voiced my concerns to James Annan and one of the authors and both agreed that this was a significant issue.

Jules Hargreaves and Gavin Schmidt have both made the point that the model used in the study is almost surely getting the LGM too warm., which their ECS value is directly based upon. They and others feel pretty confident that the ECS result is not going to be robust to model choice.

Additionally, I think it's sad to see the amount of press this paper is receiving, when others published recently examining the same time period finding sensitivities on the slightly higher end (vs. the slightly lower end) go relatively unremarked upon (e,g. here: http://www.springerlink.com/content/x112908857p234h5/). Did the New York Times, the BBC, et al. report on that paper? If so, I missed it.

Don't get me wrong- I think your coverage is better than most. But still...

As I mentioned, this post is to be followed by a substantial fresh look at the sensitivity question. I also greatly appreciated the interview you did with Nathan Urban (one of the study authors) at Tobis's Planet3 blog.

Really well done.

'O.K., fine, he didn’t say it exactly like that.'
'True, that wasn’t the language he actually used.'

Strange argument here. You seem to be saying that Obama did not say something but ... that's what he meant? Wouldn't be better to stay with what he really did say rather than trying to make a case with words which he didn't?

Go to:
http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2011/10/unforced-variation...
See comment 303 by prokaryotes

prokaryotes debunks Andreas Schmittner's paper.
“There is evidence the relationship between CO2 and surface temperatures is likely to be different [during] very cold periods than warmer.”
Andreas Schmittner used data from the last ice age. It is better to use data from a warmer period.

The opinion of most climate scientists is unchanged by Andreas Schmittner's paper.

Sere @60

“I was banned on realclimate after 3 (lengthy, study-based) posts. So I give thanks for Dot Earth this TG. And everyone who posts here shd do the same”

Care to link to your study-based comments at RC. I’ve yet to see much study-based offerings from you here at Dot Earth.

Wmar @59

“According to Ben Santer of Lawrence Livermore Lab, and noted climategate warmist, the globe has been arguably failing to warm for some 10-12 years, he further explains that by year 17 this will make a new trend, you can dead this here for your self from his own news-release:”

That’s not what he says at all. He say’s the signal can’t be separated from the noise on these shorter timescales because of natural variability of the climate system.

Santer says "Looking at a single, noisy 10-year period is cherry picking, and does not provide reliable information about the presence or absence of human effects on climate,"

Ah, cherry picking , that’s something Wmar knows something about, climate not so much.

the climate change meme is now officially (and unofficially) DEAD: D-E-A-D!. it has been replaced (most intelligently!) by concern about peak oil. here is the proof, in today's new york times op-ed, "to rethink sprawl, start with offices": http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/26/opinion/to-rethink-sprawl-start-with-o...

the author, a professor of landscape architecture at university of california, berkeley includes the following 2 sentences, while pretending to show the most minimal respect for the climate change meme:

"Rethinking pastoral capitalism is integral to creating a connected, compact metropolitan landscape that tackles rather than sidesteps a post-peak-oil future."

and

"Even leaving aside climate change, very soon the price of energy will make the dispersed, unconnected, low-density city-building pattern impossibly costly. Those jurisdictions and businesses that first create livable, workable, post-peak-oil metropolitan regions are the ones that will win the future."

good work, andy! concern about energy (real!) will now increasingly replace concern about climate change (imagined!)

it's all over but ... durban! climate change is now just a footnote and watch as the chardonnay climate change crowd runs for cover!

Mac @25 --- All the big AOGCMs contain as much actual, empirically derived physics as possible.  None contain a parameter for 'climate sensitivity'.  This last is a computed property of each AOGCM; the computed values range from 2.1 K at the low end and then on up to at least 4 K.  The two models at the lowest end have difficulty meeting various test of adequacy and may be dropped from the emsemble used for IPCC AR5.  Models in the mid-range have a climate sensitivity of 2.4--2.8 K, in decent agreement with various studies which suggest a 'most probable' value of climate sensitivity of close to 3 K.

#1: The student is not a journalist, he is a designer. Furthermore, all of the featured animals have species that are endangered or have population decline - what is not factual? I would say this is a fine example of the truth being used quite creatively. It is "cute" only for the brief moment that it is not tragic...

Sachi,

Your hubris is yet another reason companies are moving operations to the Philippines. Like me, many others have noticed your grammar and language skills are horrible. By and large, your country's IT knowledge, IT skills and bad communication have prompted companies to vote with their feet, and they are walking away from from you sir. The India call center experiment is doomed as Americans are now motivated to work for less and give so much more. I'm most appalled by your motivations and genuine lack of interest in providing real and meaningful help. I hope, until Indians can provide meaningful help, every company rejects India. The 2% great/good/humble Indians I know are the exception to the rule.

There is nothing to be proud of to have call centers in India..It is a useless job with least skills required with no future goal in sight, although it pays in the short term. We indians must get on to more satisfying and highly skilled jobs..

However, you will pay the price soon for forcing millions starving to death.
